values.alignmentText: Strong enterprise adoption provides solid demand.
Good overall, though wildfire smoke can occasionally reduce quality.
Secularism common with broad religious tolerance.
Low risk with robust institutions.
Stable banking with widespread digital payment options.
Cold-water coasts limit typical beach lifestyle.
Active hobby communities in major cities.
Subsidies exist but availability can be limited.
Urban centers offer playgrounds, parks, and family services.
Canada Child Benefit (CCB); provincial childcare subsidies; EI maternity/parental leave (up to 12–18 months combined); $10/day rollout.
Eligibility depends on residence/work status and province; many subsidies/leave accessible to work‑permit holders with SIN; documentation required.
Outdoor sports, hockey, and winter activities are popular.
Friendly yet reserved; community engagement varies.
Strict but transparent rules reduce uncertainty.
High in urban centers relative to income.
Yes—Canada recognizes dual nationality.
Stable G7 economy with steady growth and low unemployment.
Social market system with safety nets.
Strong public education and respected universities.
Available but requires labor market assessments; moderate difficulty.
Vast wilderness and generally clean urban centers align with love of nature.
Progressive tax leading to moderate-high rates.
Comfortable shoulder season in many regions: 8–18 °C (46–64 °F); earlier cool in Prairies; storms/hurricanes can affect Atlantic.
Strong social supports and family-centric culture.
Spouses and children can obtain status and benefits.
Strong mix: EI maternity/parental leave, CCB, provincial top‑ups; flexible work norms improving; varies by province/employer.
Parental leave and child benefits support families.
Many benefits available to residents with contributions; details vary by province/status; employer policies matter.
Practical chic; layers for seasons; athleisure/minimalist looks common in metros.
Climate‑driven layering; smart‑casual/athleisure; quality outerwear/boots widely worn.
Varied expectations; overall supportive of diverse expressions.
Strong industry presence in Montreal and Vancouver.
Recognition and growing acceptance of non-binary identities.
Strong legal protections and parental leave policies.
Largely egalitarian attitudes toward gender roles.
SIN, provincial health coverage (some with waiting periods), private insurance bridge; banking/lease docs; driver licence exchanges vary.
Rising wildfires and melting permafrost present moderate climate risks.
Universal coverage with generally good outcomes.
Eligibility varies by province; private insurance may be needed.
Public universities/colleges with domestic tuition; provincial grants/loans; quality varies; co‑op programs common.
International tuition higher; scholarships limited; work‑study/PGWP pathways help longer‑term access.
Housing expensive in major cities; better elsewhere.
PAYE system with annual filing; fairly straightforward.
Free public schooling; quality varies by province/district; secular curricula with options for French immersion; zoning applies.
Most work/resident visa dependents enroll as domestic; documentation/provincial rules apply; ELL supports common.
English is an official language; French widespread in Quebec.
Legal protections and strong urban acceptance.
Limited mainstream interest outside academic circles.
Encourages caregiving and emotional openness.
Plentiful tech, gaming, and parenting meetups.
Provincial rates provide modest earnings relative to cost of living.
Reliable infrastructure and fast internet nationwide.
Mountains, forests, and lakes offer abundant scenic options.
Low earthquake/hurricane risk; wildfire and extreme cold remain concerns.
Easy access to national parks and wilderness areas.
Vibrant scenes in urban centers with diverse genres.
Vibrant in Toronto/Montreal/Vancouver; quieter in smaller cities; safety generally good; earlier closing in some provinces.
Active communities like MIGS support developers.
Ubisoft, EA, BioWare, and others operate locally.
Government grants and incubators foster startups.
More relaxed in smaller cities; big-city pace manageable.
Moderate focus on extracurriculars with balanced autonomy.
Clear path after residency and presence requirements.
Low corruption with strong transparency.
Stable parliamentary democracy with rule of law.
Limited social acceptance, though legal risks are low.
Rapid expansion via $10/day childcare agreements; mix of centres/home‑based; availability varies; urban waitlists remain.
Available in major cities (secular/religious/international); tuition significant; selective admissions at top schools.
Generally progressive policies and social attitudes.
Focus on national unity and multiculturalism.
Moderate; media is largely free but concentrated.
Robust in large cities, limited in rural areas.
Low religious influence on governance.
Remote and hybrid work widely accepted post-pandemic.
Permanent residency possible within a few years.
CPP/QPP + OAS/GIS; adequacy depends on savings/housing; employer pensions/TFSA/RRSP pillars.
Immigrants can participate in public pension after residency.
Eligibility and portability tied to contributions/status; totalization treaties help; private savings advisable.
Moderate demand with pockets in startups.
Relatively low crime rates and safe streets.
High-quality public schools with French immersion and alternative programs.
Comfortable swimming mostly in mid-summer southern regions.
Cold winters and warm summers; lacks mild climate preference.
Relatively open with comprehensive sex education.
Progressive on healthcare, education, and LGBTQ rights.
Regional: West Coast mild ~8–15 °C (46–59 °F); Prairies/Central cool; variable rain; snow melt/flood risk in some areas.
High political and economic stability.
Mixed economy combining capitalism with social welfare.
Regulated capitalism supporting SMEs.
Many regions warm/hot: 20–30 °C (68–86 °F); humid in Central/East; dry/hot spells West/Prairies; wildfire smoke episodic.
Processing times moderate; fees manageable.
Moderate to high public trust in institutions.
Occasional political scandals rather than systemic issues.
Competitive salaries in major tech hubs like Toronto and Vancouver.
Outdoors, sports, errands; most retail open weekends; winter activities (skating/ski) widespread; family focus common.
Schools typically ~08:30–15:00; offices ~08:30–17:00; after‑school programs common to ~18:00; commute varies by metro.
Two weeks statutory leave plus public holidays.
Many tech roles offer three to four weeks annually.
Generally positive toward the U.S. with pragmatic caution.
Often see themselves as polite and inclusive.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Viewed favorably for stability and friendliness.
Multiple immigration streams including Express Entry.
Generally welcoming with cultural similarities.
Multicultural society and access to outdoor adventure.
Long/cold in much of country: often −20–0 °C (−4–32 °F); coastal BC milder 0–8 °C; snow/ice common outside coastal pockets.
Standard 40-hour work week with overtime protections.
Generally good boundaries, especially outside major cities.
Strong protections and union presence.
